title: Question about module generation involving the openspeedshop and python packages
body:
Summary

After a spack build of openspeedshop, I load the openspeedshop module file.   When I execute openspeedshop's "openss -cli" command.   I get python errors.   If I load the python module, then when I execute the "openss -cli" command, all is well.

I had thought that just loading the openspeedshop module would be enough for it to function properly.
Maybe that is not the expected result, so I'm posting the issue to see what is expected.

Maybe the openspeedshop spec file is supposed to add something to the module file to fix the python dependency.  I'm not sure what that would be.  It looks like spack python it accessing the system python.

Here is the scenario:

```
modules/linux-sles12-x86_64> module load openspeedshop-2.3.1-gcc-4.8-t34et3a
modules/linux-sles12-x86_64> openss -cli
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "init.py", line 27, in <module>
  File "/usr/projects/packages/openspeedshop/jegsgi/generic_spack/spack/opt/spack/linux-sles12-x86_64/gcc-4.8/python-2.7.14-buxkxinpr2nlrvl5us2zmds54zbpwpx3/lib/python2.7/shutil.py", line 12, in <module>
    import collections
  File "/usr/projects/packages/openspeedshop/jegsgi/generic_spack/spack/opt/spack/linux-sles12-x86_64/gcc-4.8/python-2.7.14-buxkxinpr2nlrvl5us2zmds54zbpwpx3/lib/python2.7/collections.py", line 20, in <module>
    from _collections import deque, defaultdict
ImportError: /usr/lib/python2.7/lib-dynload/_collections.so: wrong ELF class: ELFCLASS32
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
Welcome to OpenSpeedShop 2.3.1
openss>>NameError: name 'myparse' is not defined
```

If I load the python module, then openspeedshop functions as expected.

modules/linux-sles12-x86_64> module load python-2.7.14-gcc-4.8-buxkxin
modules/linux-sles12-x86_64> openss -cli
openss>>Welcome to OpenSpeedShop 2.3.1
openss>>help

Open|SpeedShop is a performance tool brought
to you by The Krell Institute and sponsors.
 


### Expected Result

What you expected

I had thought that just loading the openspeedshop module would be enough for it to function properly.
Maybe that is not the expected result, that is why I'm asking.
Maybe the openspeedshop spec file is supposed to add something to the module file to fix the python dependency.  I'm not sure what that would be.  It looks like spack python it accessing the system python.

### Actual Result

What happened instead

I had to load the python module that was used as part of the openspeedshop build.

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```
I used this command to build:

$ spack install openspeedshop +cbtf+mpich %gcc@4.8

```

### Information on your system
```
This includes: 
1. which platform you are using

linux-sles12-x86_64/gcc-4.8> uname -a
Linux tt-fey1 4.4.114-94.11-default #1 SMP Thu Feb 1 19:28:26 UTC 2018 (4309ff9) x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

 2. any relevant configuration detail (custom `packages.yaml` or `modules.yaml`, etc.)
linux-sles12-x86_64/gcc-4.8> cat ~/.spack/linux/packages.yaml 
packages:
   all:
      providers:
         pkgconfig: [pkg-config]
   mpich:
      buildable: False
      paths:
         mpich@7.6.2%gcc@4.8 arch=cray-CNL-haswell: /opt/cray/pe/mpt/7.7.0/gni/mpich-gnu/5.1

```
